I can't believe we're discussing this.

HTTP doesn't make any guarantee about the idempotence of POST. Thus a 
client can not rely on it, unless it has additional information. In 
absence of that information, it has to assume it's not idempotent.

And no, there's no reason not to do idempotent things with POST, it's 
just *better* for everybody to use an idempotent message instead (*).


Best regards, Julian

(*) Such as ADDMEMBER. <ducks>
